elements.name: part_one_text
elements.html:
This section is about your background and risk factors for cardiomyopathy. We will use this information to study the impact of environmental factors on cardiomyopathy – for example, how environmental factors influence age of onset and severity. We will also examine how genes and environmental factors interact to cause cardiomyopathy.

You control this data – we will not share it with other organisations or companies, unless you explicitly choose to release this data to researchers within the Heart Hive.

elements.name: DIAGNOSIS
elements.title: What type of cardiomyopathy have you been diagnosed with?

elements.name: FHX
elements.title: Does anyone else in your family (blood relatives) have cardiomyopathy?

elements.title: Does anyone else in your family (blood relatives) have the same type of cardiomyopathy as you?

elements.title: In total how many people in your family (blood relatives) have cardiomyopathy?

elements.name: CAD
elements.title: CAD
elements.html:
Coronary artery disease - a problem with the blood supply to the heart, e.g. due to narrowing, furring, or blockage of the arteries or blood vessels supplying the heart - can cause cardiomyopathy.

Please select the following that apply to you:

elements.name: CAD.NARROWING
elements.title: Have you been told you have narrowed or blocked arteries or blood vessels around your heart?

elements.name: CAD.IHD
elements.title: Have you been told that you have ischaemic heart disease?

elements.name: CAD.ICM
elements.title: Have you been told that your cardiomyopathy is due to a problem with the blood supply to the heart (ischaemia or ischaemic heart disease)?

elements.name: CAD.CABG
elements.title: Have you ever had a heart bypass graft (CABG)?

elements.name: CAD.PCA
elements.title: Have you ever had an angiogram and procedure to open a blocked artery  or blood vessel to the heart (PCA or PCI)?

elements.name: CAD.STENT
elements.title: Have you ever had an angiogram and procedure to open a blocked artery or blood vessel to the heart (PCI or PCA)

elements.name: CAD.THROMBOLYSIS
elements.title: Have you ever had thrombolysis (clot-busting injection) for a heart attack

elements.name: CAD.NORMALANGIO
elements.title: Have you had an angiogram that showed the blood supply to your heart was normal?

elements.name: CAD.OTHEREXCLUDE
elements.title: Have you had any other tests that showed you do not have any narrowing or blockage of arteries or blood vessels around your heart
elements.otherErrorText: A description is required for choices of "Yes".

elements.name: valve_text
elements.title: VALVE
elements.html:
Heart valve problems (narrowed or leaky valves) can cause cardiomyopathy. Sometimes cardiomyopathy can lead to heart valve problems.

If you have a heart valve problem, it is helpful to know if it started before or after your cardiomyopathy.

elements.name: VALVE
elements.title: Have you ever had any kind of heart valve problem, now or in the past?

elements.name: VALVE_PRIOR
elements.title: Have you ever had any kind of heart valve problem before your cardiomyopathy, or been told that your valve problem caused your cardiomyopathy?

elements.name: valve_type_text
elements.title: ValveType
elements.html:
There are four chambers in your heart and the valves make sure that the blood flows through them in one direction.
If the valve does not close properly, it will allow blood to leak backwards. This is called valve incompetence, or regurgitation, or a leaky valve.
If your valve does not open fully, it will obstruct the flow of blood. This is called valve stenosis or narrowing.

elements.name: VALVE_AORTIC
elements.title: Please select the option that best describes your aortic valve:
elements.description: Your Aortic valve opens to allow blood to flow from your heart to your aorta, the main blood vessel supplying your body.

elements.name: VALVE_MITRAL
elements.title: Please select the option that best describes your mitral valve:
elements.description: Your Mitral valve opens to allow blood to flow between the chambers (left atrium and left ventricle) of your heart.

elements.name: VALVE_PULMONARY
elements.title: Please select the option that best describes your pulmonary valve:
elements.description: Your Pulmonary valve opens to allow blood to flow from your heart to your lungs.

elements.name: VALVE_AR_GRADE
elements.title: Which of the following best matches the description of your aortic valve problem?
elements.description: Valve problems can be very variable.  It is helpful to know how leaky your aortic valve is (or if it has been treated how leaky it was).

elements.name: VALVE_AS_GRADE
elements.title: Which of the following best matches the description of your aortic valve problem?
elements.description: Valve problems can be very variable. It is helpful to know how narrowed your aortic valve is (or if it has been treated how narrowed it was).

elements.name: VALVE_MR_GRADE
elements.title: Which of the following best matches the description of your mitral valve problem?
elements.description: Valve problems can be very variable. It is helpful to know how leaky your mitral valve is (or if it has been treated how leaky it was).

elements.name: VALVE_MS_GRADE
elements.title: Which of the following best matches the description of your mitral valve problem?
elements.description: Valve problems can be very variable.  It is helpful to know how narrowed your mitral valve is (or if it has been treated how narrowed it was).

elements.name: VALVE_PR_GRADE
elements.title: Which of the following best matches the description of your pulmonary valve problem?
elements.description: Valve problems can be very variable. It is helpful to know how leaky your pulmonary valve is (or if it has been treated how leaky it was).

elements.name: VALVE_PS_GRADE
elements.title: Which of the following best matches the description of your pulmonary valve problem?
elements.description: Valve problems can be very variable. It is helpful to know how narrowed your pulmonary  valve is (or if it has been treated how narrowed it was).

elements.name: chd_text
elements.title: CHD_text
elements.html: Congenital heart disease (for example a hole in the heart) changes the way blood flows through the heart. This can change the shape and function of the chambers of the heart leading to cardiomyopathy

elements.name: CHD
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with congenital heart disease, or did you need surgery on your heart as a child?

elements.name: CHD_TEXT
elements.title: If yes, please provide details

I used to have high blood pressure, but it is well controlled now
I currently have high blood pressure

elements.name: HTN_SEQUENCE
elements.title: Which was diagnosed first, your cardiomyopathy or your high blood pressure?

elements.name: CHOL

choices.text: I have never had high cholesterol
I used to have high cholesterol, but it is well controlled now

choices.text: Immediately, and I continue to use insulin
Immediately, but only for a few days or weeks until my sugars were controlled and then I stopped.
I have only been given insulin in an emergency

elements.name: sex_explainer_text
elements.html:
Men and women have different risk factors for cardiomyopathy, particularly your genes and sex hormones.

We ask about your sex at birth because it can help researchers make new discoveries about how the sex you were born with affects health and risk of disease. It is also important when processing biological samples in the lab

elements.name: SEX
elements.title: What sex was assigned to you at birth?
elements.description: A question about gender identity will follow
elements.otherErrorText: A description is required for choices of "other".

elements.name: GENDER_DIFFERENCE
elements.title: Is your gender identity the same as the sex you were assigned at birth?

elements.name: GENDER
elements.title: Select the option that best describes your current gender identity

choices.text: I don't identify with any option provided

elements.otherErrorText: A description is required for choices of "other".

elements.name: part2_text
elements.html:
The following questions are about how your cardiomyopathy affects you - for example the age of onset and how severe it is.

We will use this information to examine how genes and environmental factors interact to cause cardiomyopathy and influence the age of onset and severity.

You control this data and we will not share it with other organisations or companies, unless you choose to release this data to researchers within the Heart Hive.

elements.name: AGE_ONSET
elements.title: How old were you when your cardiomyopathy was diagnosed?

elements.name: CARDIOLOGIST
elements.title: Please enter the name of your cardiologist:

elements.name: HOSPITAL
elements.title: Please enter the name of the hospital:

elements.name: CMR
elements.title: Have you had a cardiac MRI (CMR) scan?

elements.name: CMR_SITE
elements.title: Please enter the name of the hospital where you had your scan:

elements.name: CMR_REPORT
elements.title: Do you have a copy of your cardiac MRI (CMR) scan report?

elements.name: ECG
elements.title: Have you had an ECG?

elements.name: GENETIC_TESTED
elements.title: Have you had genetic testing for cardiomyopathy?

elements.name: GENETIC_TESTED_SITE
elements.title: Which hospital did you have your genetic test at?

elements.name: GENETIC_TESTED_RESULT
elements.title: What was the result of your genetic test?

choices.text: A genetic variant of uncertain significance - might be the cause of my cardiomyopathy, but further testing needed

elements.otherErrorText: A description is required for choices of "other".

elements.name: GENE_NAME_DIAGNOSTIC
elements.title: Please enter the name of the gene identified as the cause of your cardiomyopathy.
elements.description: (For example, TTN, Titin or MYH7)

elements.name: GENETIC_TESTED_REPORT_AVAIL
elements.title: Do you have a copy of your genetic test result?

elements.name: EVENTS_STROKE
elements.title: Have you ever had a stroke or mini-stroke?

choices.text: Yes, at the time my cardiomyopathy was diagnosed

elements.name: EVENTS_AF
elements.title: Have you ever had atrial fibrillation?
elements.description: An irregular heartbeat, usually fast

choices.text: Yes, at the time my cardiomyopathy was diagnosed

elements.name: EVENTS_PPM
elements.title: Have you had a pacemaker?

choices.text: Yes, at the time my cardiomyopathy was diagnosed

elements.name: EVENTS_ICD
elements.title: Do you have an ICD?
elements.description: Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator insertion - small device which can treat people with dangerously abnormal heart rhythms. Some ICDs also act as pacemakers, if yours does select 'pacemaker' above too.

choices.text: Yes, at the time my cardiomyopathy was diagnosed

elements.name: EVENTS_CRT
elements.title: Do you have CRT?
elements.description:
CRT – cardiac resynchronisation therapy (biventricular pacing) – this is a special type of pacemaker that helps the left and right side of the heart beat in time with each other.  It has 3 leads.
This device often has a defibrillator – if yours does tick ‘ICD’ above too.

choices.text: Yes, at the time my cardiomyopathy was diagnosed

elements.name: EVENTS_ARREST
elements.title: Have you ever had a cardiac arrest?
elements.description: When your heart suddenly stops pumping blood around your body, usually because of a problem with electrical signals in your heart.

choices.text: Yes, at the time my cardiomyopathy was diagnosed

elements.name: ICD_PRIMARY_PREV
elements.title: Was your ICD implanted because you had had a life-threatening heart rhythm problem or a cardiac arrest?

elements.name: ICD_SHOCK
elements.title: Since you have had your ICD has it ever given you a shock because of a serious heart rhythm problem or cardiac arrest?

elements.name: ICD_INAPPROPRIATE
elements.title: Since you have had your ICD has it ever given you an ‘inappropriate shock’?

elements.name: EVENTS_LVAD
elements.title: Have you ever had an LVAD implanted?
elements.description: Left ventricular assist device LVAD – is a kind of artificial heart pump. It is used to treat people with severe heart failure and is sometimes given to people on the waiting list for a heart transplant.

elements.name: EVENTS_TX_LIST
elements.title: Have you ever been entered on the heart transplant list?

elements.name: EVENTS_TRANSPLANT
elements.title: Have you had a heart transplant?

elements.name: LVOT_OBSTRUCT
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with left ventricular outflow obstruction?
elements.description: Sometimes, if the septum of your heart is very thickened, it can get in the way of blood flowing out of the heart.  This is called left ventricular outflow obstruction.

elements.name: SEPTAL_REDUCTION
elements.title: Have you had treatment to reduce the size of your septum (septal reduction), including surgery or ablation?
elements.description: If the septum is very thick it can be treated to reduce its size:  Treatments include surgery to remove some of the septum (myomectomy) or injecting alcohol to disrupt the blood supply to the septum and shrink it (alcohol septal ablation)

elements.name: RESEARCH
elements.title: Have you ever taken part in other medical or health research?

elements.name: RESEARCH_TEXT
elements.title: If yes please give the name of each study:

elements.name: secondary_causes_text
elements.html:
This is the final section of the survey.

There are two questions about rare causes of cardiomyopathy. We will use this information to examine how genes and environmental factors interact to cause cardiomyopathy. and influence the age of onset and severity. 

You control this data - we will not share this data with other organisations or companies unless you explicitly chose to release this data to other researchers within the Heart Hive.


There are lots of conditions or diseases that can sometimes cause cardiomyopathy. Our genes determine how we respond to different environmental factors, including medicines, infections, and toxins etc,. Most people who have experienced one of the 'risk factors' below will not develop cardiomyopathy - but it is very helpful to know who has been exposed and to compare this to your genetic data. This could identify the exact genes that make someone more sensitive to these factors.

elements.name: DIAG_NMD
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with Neuromuscular Diseases or muscular dystrophy
elements.description: Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD), Friedreich's ataxia, Myotonic dystrophy

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_INFLAM
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with inflammatory/ infiltrative conditions
elements.description: Myocarditis, Haemochromatosis, Sarcoid

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_METABOLIC
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with nutritional deficiency and metabolic disorders
elements.description: Low calcium (Hypocalcaemia), Low phosphate (Hypophosphataemia), High urea (Uraemia), Cushing disease, Growth hormone too high (Acromegaly), Thyroid hormone too high or too low (Hyperthyroid or Hypothyroid), Phaeochromocytoma, Deficiency of carnitine, thiamine or selenium

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_CHEMICALS
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with chemical/toxin poisoning?
elements.description: Carbon monoxide poisoning, Cobalt, lead or mercury poisoning

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_VIRUS
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with one of the following viral infections?
elements.description: Adenovirus, Coxsackie A and B, Cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr, Human herpes virus, Parvovirus B19, Varicella

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_OTHER_INFECTIONS
elements.title: Have you ever been diagnosed with any of the following infections?
elements.description: Brucellosis, Diphtheria, Psittacosis, Typhoid fever, Tuberculosis or Mycobacteria, Chagas disease, Schistosomiasis, Toxoplasmosis, Ricketts

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_VASCULITIS
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with vasculitis
elements.description: Churg-Strauss, Kawasaki disease, Polyarteritis nodosa

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_CONN_TISSUE
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with a connective tissue disease?
elements.description: Dermatomyositis, Scleroderma

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: DIAG_LUPUS
elements.title: Have you been diagnosed with an autoimmune condition
elements.description: Lupus (SLE, Systemic lupus erythematosus)

choices.text: Yes, my doctor told me this caused my cardiomyopathy

elements.name: SECONDARY_CAUSE_TEXT
elements.title: If you said yes to any of the above please expand on your diagnosis or if you know the cause of your cardiomyopathy, but it was not mentioned above, please enter it here:

elements.name: medications_explainer_text
elements.html: Some medications or drugs can cause cardiomyopathy. Our genes determine how we respond to different medications in the same way that our genes determine how sensitive our hearts are to other risk factors. Most people wjho take these medications will not develop cardiomyopathy.

elements.name: MEDICATION
elements.title: Please enter the medication you take for your cardiomyopathy

elements.name: MEDICATION_TEXT
elements.title: If you can't find your medication in the drop down list, please enter the name(s) here

elements.name: end_text
elements.html: Once you have submitted your survey you cannot return to it and make changes. Are you ready to submit?

questionTemplates.name: cm_type
questionTemplates.title: Cardiomyopathy type?

choices.text: ACM or ARVC - Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy, Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy

questionTemplates.otherErrorText: A description is required for choices of "other".
